Literature Review: The type III secretion system (T3SS) is a conserved export machinery that plays a crucial role in the functioning of both the bacterial flagellum and the injectisome. The T3SS is responsible for secreting components that self-assemble into extracellular appendages, as well as directly translocating modulating effector proteins from the bacterial cell into the infected host in the case of the injectisome. The molecular similarities and differences between the T3SS of the flagellum and the injectisome have been the subject of intense interest, with recent advances in cryo-electron microscopy technologies providing significant insights into their structure and function. This review aims to summarize the current understanding of the structural insights into the T3SS of the bacterial flagellum and injectisome, highlighting the molecular similarities and differences that underlie their diverse functions.
